author: China Insights-SOHTV
description:
🎓 16 years of study. One dream: escape village life.
But for millions of young Chinese graduates, that dream is being crushed by a broken job market. With over 11 million grads and nowhere to go, the government’s latest plan is simple — “New Agricultural Revitalization.” Translation? Go back home and raise pigs.
#ChinaYouthCrisis #Unemployment #NewAgriculturalRevitalization #CollegeGrads #PigFarming #ChineseEconomy #Gaokao #DeadEndJobs
title: Escape the Village… to Raise Pigs?!

author: China Insights-SOHTV
description:
One student cracked under Gaokao pressure —
tore up his test and his classmates’.
Dreams shredded. Silence followed.
Welcome to China’s most intense exam.
📄🔥 #Gaokao #ExamMeltdown #ChinaReality
title: 12 Years of Study… Gone in 10 Seconds

author: China Insights-SOHTV
description:
In China, rotten bananas aren’t thrown away—they’re turned into “premium” durian cakes.
From industrial flavoring to veterinary drugs, this viral dessert is a chemical cocktail wrapped in sweetness.
Here's how a trash-tier ingredient becomes a bakery best-seller.

#china #durian #streetfood
title: Trash to Cake: How to Turns Garbage into “Food”

author: China Insights-SOHTV
description:
#food security  #crop disease  #foreign interference
Two researchers from overseas were caught bringing a highly dangerous plant sample into the U.S.—one known to devastate crops and contaminate food chains. The incident raises serious questions: Was this just poor judgment, or something far more calculated?

This toxin-producing organism targets wheat, corn, and rice—vital parts of the American food system. Under the right conditions, it can slash yields by up to 80%. The economic ripple effects? Massive.

Meanwhile, some foreign institutions have been stockpiling grain and sending "talent" abroad through certain recruitment programs. The individuals involved? Tied to labs, funding sources, and affiliations that many would find… surprising.

We take a closer look at what happens when scientific collaboration meets national interest—and when lab coats cover more than just research.

🎯 Subscribe for more investigations into global influence, research ethics, and what’s really growing i
title: Feed the Party, Starve the West|China Insights|

author: China Insights-SOHTV
description: In China, when disaster hits, the first responders aren’t medics or rescuers—they’re photographers. From staged “heroic” rescues to helicopters posing for press, tragedy becomes propaganda. While people beg for help, the cameras roll. This is disaster relief, not for saving lives—but for saving face.
title: Tripods Before Troops
